item.title: Incrementer Test
item.description: In my last two posts I covered the construction of the upper and lower incrementer cards. The lower card is a 16-bit half adder and the upper card is a 16-bit register.

item.title: Incrementer Construction (Part 1 of 2)
item.description: We’re getting nearer and nearer to a computer that can run though a program in memory rather than just a single instruction … we’ve got memory to hold the program and a program counter to point to the current instruction in memory.

item.title: Incrementer Design
item.description: In my last post I covered the design of the 16-bit half adder which takes whatever value is currently on the address bus and increments it by one.

item.title: Incrementer Design: 16-bit Half Adder
item.description: In the last post I introduced the design for the 1-bit Half Adder. This post covers connecting sixteen of these units together to make the 16-bit Half Adder.

item.title: Incrementer Design: 1-bit Half Adder
item.description: Typical isn’t it?! … you wait 10 months for a post and then two come along at once. Well, all being well, this should be the first of a short flurry of posts as I move on to the design of the incrementer.
